titleStmt.title: The royal prerogative vindicated in the converted recusant convinced by Scripture, reasons, fathers, and councils, that the oath of abjuration (compared with those of allegiance, and supremacy) containeth nothing, but what may be lawfully taken by every pious Christian, and loyal subject; and that the known doctrine, and discipline of the Church of England, in opposition to Popery on the one hand, and all sects, and schisms on the other, is the safest way to peace and loyalty here, and salvation hereafter. To which is annexed The King's supremacy in all causes, ecclesiastical, and civil, asserted in a sermon preached at the assises at Monmouth before Sir Robert Hide, one of his Majestie's judges, March 30. 1661. / By John Cragge, M.A.
titleStmt.author: Cragge, John, M.A.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by T.R. for H. Twyford, N. Brooke, Tho. Dring, and John Place,

notesStmt.note: "The King's supremacy in all causes ecclesiastical, and civil" (Wing (2nd ed., 1994) C6786) has separate dated title page, register and pagination.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
